transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing your experiences with the Positive Data Log. Can you share some of the challenges you've faced in finding evidence for new, more balanced beliefs?

Patient: It's been difficult because I feel like my negative beliefs are so deeply ingrained. When I try to think of evidence against them, my mind goes blank, or I dismiss the evidence as not strong enough.

Therapist: That's a common challenge when working on shifting long-held beliefs. Our negative beliefs can be like a filter that colors how we see ourselves and the world around us. It takes practice to start recognizing and giving weight to evidence that doesn't fit with those beliefs. Can you share an example of a situation where you struggled to find evidence for a new belief?

Patient: Well, I had a customer leave a really positive review for one of my handmade crafts. They praised my creativity and attention to detail. But instead of feeling good about it, I found myself thinking that they were just being nice or that they didn't really mean it.

Therapist: That's a great example. It shows how our negative beliefs can lead us to discount or dismiss evidence that contradicts them. In this case, your core belief that you're fundamentally unlovable or flawed may have made it hard to accept the genuine praise from your customer. What do you think would happen if you allowed yourself to consider that their positive review was sincere and accurate?

Patient: I guess it would challenge my belief that my work isn't valuable or that I'm not talented enough. It would be evidence against that negative belief.

Therapist: Exactly. That's the power of the Positive Data Log - it helps us start to collect and give weight to evidence that supports new, more balanced beliefs. As we gather more evidence, it becomes harder to maintain those old, negative beliefs. It's a gradual process, but over time, it can lead to significant shifts in how we see ourselves and the world around us. Does that make sense?

Patient: Yeah, I can see how that would work. It's just hard to do in the moment when those negative thoughts feel so strong.

Therapist: You're absolutely right. It takes practice and persistence. That's why we start small and build up over time. Let's look at another example from your week. Can you think of a situation where you had a negative thought or belief, and walk me through how you might use the Positive Data Log to challenge it?

Patient: Okay, let me think. Well, I was invited to a social event with some acquaintances from the LGBTQ+ community, but my first thought was that they only invited me out of pity or obligation, not because they really wanted me there.

Therapist: That's a great example. Let's use the downward arrow technique to identify the underlying beliefs. If it were true that they only invited you out of pity or obligation, what would that mean about you?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not someone people genuinely want to spend time with. That I'm not interesting or likable enough on my own.

Therapist: And if that were true, that you're not interesting or likable enough, what would that mean about you as a person?

Patient: It would mean that there's something fundamentally wrong with me. That I'm just not good enough.

Therapist: So we can see how that initial thought connects to your core belief that you're fundamentally unlovable or flawed. Now let's look at how we might use the Positive Data Log to challenge that belief. What evidence do you have that contradicts the idea that you're not interesting or likable enough?

Patient: Well, I guess the fact that they invited me at all is evidence that they want to spend time with me. And in the past, when I have gone to social events, I've usually been able to connect with people and have good conversations.

Therapist: That's great evidence to include in your Positive Data Log. What about evidence that you are interesting and likable?

Patient: I have a few close friends who seem to genuinely enjoy my company. And I've had customers and people in my yoga class tell me that they find me interesting and insightful.

Therapist: Excellent. Those are all strong pieces of evidence to include in your log. As you continue to collect evidence like this, it will become harder and harder to maintain that negative core belief. The key is to practice noticing and recording the evidence, even when it feels uncomfortable or goes against your initial thoughts. Does this help clarify how to use the Positive Data Log?

Patient: Yes, it definitely helps to break it down like that. I can see how I need to be more intentional about looking for and recording evidence, even when my negative thoughts are loud.

Therapist: You're absolutely right. It takes practice and intentionality. And remember, you don't have to believe the evidence 100% at first. The goal is just to start noticing and giving it some weight, rather than dismissing it outright. As we continue to work together, we'll keep practicing this skill and building up your Positive Data Log.

Patient: Okay, that makes sense. I'll keep working on it.

Therapist: Great. Remember, this is a skill that takes time to develop, so be patient with yourself. Let's move on to discussing some additional strategies for managing overwhelming emotions. You mentioned that you've been using the distress tolerance techniques we discussed, like the 5-4-3-2-1 grounding exercise and radical acceptance. How have those been working for you?
